directives.description: Marks an element of a GraphQL schema as no longer supported.
directives.name: deprecated

directives.description: Directs the executor to include this field or fragment only when the `if` argument is true.
directives.name: include

directives.description: Directs the executor to skip this field or fragment when the `if` argument is true.
directives.name: skip

args.description: The URL that specifies the behavior of this scalar.
args.name: url

directives.description: Exposes a URL that specifies the behavior of this scalar.
directives.name: specifiedBy

types.description: Represents a directive

fields.deprecationReason: Check `locations` field for enum value FIELD
fields.name: onField

fields.deprecationReason: Check `locations` field for enum value FRAGMENT_SPREAD
fields.name: onFragment

fields.deprecationReason: Check `locations` field for enum value OPERATION
fields.name: onOperation

types.name: __Directive

types.description: Represents a schema
types.name: __Schema

types.description: Represents scalars, interfaces, object types, unions, enums in the system
types.name: __Type

types.description: A stored representation of a Web3 address.
types.name: Address

types.description:
The address (40 (hex) characters / 160 bits / 20 bytes) is derived from the public key (128 (hex) characters /
512 bits / 64 bytes) which is derived from the private key (64 (hex) characters / 256 bits / 32 bytes).

The address is actually the last 40 characters of the keccak-256 hash of the public key with `0x` appended.
types.name: AddressHash

types.description:
A package of data that contains zero or more transactions, the hash of the previous block ("parent"), and optionally
other data. Because each block (except for the initial "genesis block") points to the previous block, the data
structure that they form is called a "blockchain".
types.name: Block

types.description: The `Boolean` scalar type represents `true` or `false`.
types.name: Boolean

types.description: Represents a CELO or usd token transfer between addresses.
types.name: CeloTransfer

types.description:
An unpadded hexadecimal number with 0 or more digits. Each pair of digits
maps directly to a byte in the underlying binary representation. When
interpreted as a number, it should be treated as big-endian.
types.name: Data

types.description:
The `DateTime` scalar type represents a date and time in the UTC
timezone. The DateTime appears in a JSON response as an ISO8601 formatted
string, including UTC timezone ("Z"). The parsed date and time string will
be converted to UTC if there is an offset.
types.name: DateTime

types.description:
The `Decimal` scalar type represents signed double-precision fractional
values parsed by the `Decimal` library. The Decimal appears in a JSON
response as a string to preserve precision.
types.name: Decimal

types.description: A 32-byte [KECCAK-256](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SHA-3) hash.
types.name: FullHash

types.description:
The `ID` scalar type represents a unique identifier, often used to
refetch an object or as key for a cache. The ID type appears in a JSON
response as a String; however, it is not intended to be human-readable.
When expected as an input type, any string (such as `"4"`) or integer
(such as `4`) input value will be accepted as an ID.
types.name: ID

types.description:
The `Int` scalar type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric
values. It is NOT compliant with the GraphQl spec, it can represent
values between `-(2^53 - 1)` and `2^53 - 1` as specified by
[IEEE 754](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_754).
It is kept here for backwards compatibility, prefer using
the SpecCompliantInt.
types.name: Int

types.description: Models internal transactions.
types.name: InternalTransaction

types.description:
The `JSON` scalar type represents arbitrary JSON string data, represented as UTF-8
character sequences. The JSON type is most often used to represent a free-form
human-readable JSON string.
types.name: Json

types.description: The nonce (16 (hex) characters / 128 bits / 8 bytes) is derived from the Proof-of-Work.
types.name: NonceHash

fields.description: When paginating forwards, the cursor to continue.
fields.name: endCursor

fields.description: When paginating forwards, are there more items?
fields.name: hasNextPage

fields.description: When paginating backwards, are there more items?
fields.name: hasPreviousPage

fields.description: When paginating backwards, the cursor to continue.
fields.name: startCursor

fields.description: Gets token transfers by token contract address hash.
fields.name: tokenTransfers

types.description:
The representation of a verified Smart Contract.

"A contract in the sense of Solidity is a collection of code (its functions)
and data (its state) that resides at a specific address on the Ethereum
blockchain."
http://solidity.readthedocs.io/en/v0.4.24/introduction-to-smart-contracts.html
types.name: SmartContract

types.description:
The `String` scalar type represents textual data, represented as UTF-8
character sequences. The String type is most often used by GraphQL to
represent free-form human-readable text.
types.name: String

types.description: Represents a token.
types.name: Token

types.description: Represents a token transfer between addresses.
types.name: TokenTransfer

types.description: Models a Web3 transaction.
types.name: Transaction

types.description: Represents a CELO token transfer between addresses.
types.name: TransferTransaction

types.description:
The smallest fractional unit of Ether. Using wei instead of ether allows code to do integer match instead of using
floats.

See [Ethereum Homestead Documentation](http://ethdocs.org/en/latest/ether.html) for examples of various denominations of wei.

Etymology of "wei" comes from [Wei Dai ()](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wei_Dai), a
[cypherpunk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cypherpunk) who came up with b-money, which outlined modern
cryptocurrencies.
types.name: Wei
